header.description: Experimental heat capacity and comparison to calculated data for the crystalline phase of poly(l-histidine) (PLHIS).

row.label: default
row.description: Smoothed experimental Cp data
Calculated solid Cp agrees with experimental data (< 3%)
Calculated liquid Cp agrees with experimental data (< 5%)
Linearly extrapolated experimental liquid Cp data
Calculated solid Cp lacks comparison with experimental data (> 3%)
Calculated liquid Cp lacks comparison with experimental data (> 5%)
Crystalline Cp data approximated by the Cp data of glass
Glassy Cp data approximated by the Cp data of crystals

data-table.name: Explanations on Fit to Experimental Data

header.title: Explanations on Fit to Experimental Data

row.label: default
row.description: All contributions used in addition scheme were derived from experimental data
Heat capacities calculated using Tarasov function.
Computed from the least squares fit of the experimental data. Some or all contributions used in addition scheme were derived by linear extrapolation of the melts.
Liquid Cp derived from regression of data obtained for the homologous series.

header.title: Extended Substance Data on Poly(L-histidine) (PLHIS)
header.description: Data on poly(l-histidine) (PLHIS) relevant to the computation of thermal properties.

preview-content.content: residual entropy at zero temperature S0 in the crystalline state
intramolecular vibrational parameter θ1 for the skeletal heat capacity to compute Cp using the Tarasov function in the crystalline phase
intermolecular vibrational parameter θ3 for the skeletal heat capacity to compute Cp using the Tarasov function in the crystalline phase
number of skeletal vibrational modes Ns used in the Tarasov equation in the crystalline phase
temperature range of the ATHAS recommended experimental heat capacity data for the crystalline phase

footer.title: Comments
footer.description: Comments on the Extended Substance Data table

footer-content.content: See below for an explanation of symbols.
Temperature range of the ATHAS recommended experimental heat capacity data: Heat capacities for semicrystalline polymers were used as approximation for the solid phase.

Note that all data are chosen to be a close approximation to equilibrium crystals and its superheated state or equilibrium melt and its supercooled state. The normally found solids are often metastable, semicrystalline. The melting and glass transition behavior of these can be used for characterization of the structure, as described in Ref. []. The heat capacites and integral thermal properties H, S, G are well represented by adding the appropriate fractional portions according to the weight fraction crystallinity.

row.description: Glass transition temperature in Kelvin, taken at the half-vitrification at about 1…10 K·min−1 if available. See Ref. [] of the list of publications.

row.label: ∆Cp
row.description: The change in the heat capacity, listed in J/(K·mol), at the glass transition temperature Tg. The first number in parentheses refers to the small beads that make up the repeating unit. The average increase in Cp at Tg of all listed molecules is 11.5±1.7 J/(K·mol). The second number refers to large beads. The increase in Cp of a large bead at Tg is double or triple that of a small bead.
Melting temperature in Kelvin. Equilibrium melting temperature estimated from experimental data or extrapolated from the melting of small crystals.

row.label: ∆Hf
row.description: The heat of fusion of repeating unit in kJ/K. It is computed for 100% crystallinity.
Residual entropy in the glassy state at zero temperature, in J/(K·mol).

row.label: Θ1 and Θ3
row.description: Parameters for the skeletal heat capacity needed to compute Cp using the Tarasov function (Θ1: intramolecular vibrations, Θ3: intermolecular vibrations). Freqency given in Kelvin. See Ref. [] of the list of publications.

The number of skeletal vibrational modes used in the Tarasov equation with the Θ temperatures of the previous two columns. Values of Θ temperatures in parentheses are estimates based on data from polymers of similar backbone structure. The group vibration frequencies (Ng) are usually tabulated in the listed references: Ns + Ng is the number of degrees of freedom (three times the number of atoms in the repeating units).

row.label: Cp temperature range
row.description: Temperature range of the ATHAS recommended experimental heat capacity data in Kelvin. The computations of heat capacities of solids are based on these data and are usually carried out from 0.1 to 1000 K, to provide sufficiently broad ranges of temperature for the addition schemes and for analysis of superheated polymers, as in laser ablation studies.
The Lindemann constant in mK·mol/J.

row.full-reference: Wunderlich, B.: Macromolecular Physics. Vol. 3: Crystal Melting. Academic Press, New York, NY 1980.
Pan, R., Varma-Nair, M., Wunderlich, B.: J. Thermal Analysis 35 (1989) 955.
Roles, K.: Ph.D. dissertation, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 1991.
Xenopoulos, A., Roles, K., Wunderlich, B.: Polymer 34 (1993) 2559.
Wunderlich, B.: Thermal Analysis of Polymeric Materials. 894+xvi pages, 947 figures. Springer-Verlag, Berlin 2005.
